fields.name: Hot Water
fields.content: Many of us don't realize that using water uses energy. In fact, supplying your home with hot water uses a lot of energy. Your hot water tank has to keep around 60 gallons of water at more than 100°F all day long. Hot water accounts for about 15% of the average household’s energy bill."Where Does My Money Go?" ENERGY STAR. n.d. 19 Jan 2010 By becoming more aware of your hot water use, and installing a few low-cost upgrades, you can easily reduce this number. The following steps will help you be more mindful and use your hot water more efficiently.
fields.teaser: Hot water accounts for about 15-20% of the average household’s energy bill. By becoming more aware of your hot water use, and installing a few low-cost upgrades, you can easily reduce this number.

fields.name: Electricity
fields.content: You may already be taking steps like turning off the lights when you leave a room, but some sources of electricity waste are more difficult to spot. These actions will help you maximize your electricity savings by identifying these sources.

fields.name: Air Sealing & Insulation
fields.content:
While improving your home's heating and cooling system is important, you'll see the biggest improvements by focusing on air sealing and insulation. In addition to lowering energy bills, proper air sealing and insulation will also create a healthier home with better air quality and fewer allergens. 

"Air sealing" refers to closing gaps in a house, preventing unwanted drafts and air leakage. "Insulation" is a material that limits heat flow. Insulation is like putting on a sweater; air sealing is like zipping up your coat. As you know from walking outside on a cold day, the warmest coat is almost useless if it's left open. The same is true in your home: installing insulation should go hand-in-hand with improved air sealing.

fields.name: Heating & Cooling
fields.content: Your heating and cooling system is the single biggest contributor to your home's overall energy bill."Where Does My Money Go?" ENERGY STAR. n.d. 19 Jan. 2010 While buying new equipment may make sense for some older, out-of-date systems, these upgrades can be quite pricey. Instead of investing in expensive improvements, you can see big savings simply by getting the most out of the equipment already in your home. These low- and no-cost steps will give you a big return on your investment and significantly reduce your energy use.

fields.name: Appliances
fields.content: Appliances - like your refrigerator, dish washer, and clothes dryer - account for 13% of the average home's energy bill."Where Does My Money Go?" ENERGY STAR. n.d. 19 Jan. 2010 These actions will help you use your appliances more efficiently and decide whether it's time to upgrade to a newer model.

fields.name: Home Audits
fields.content: Having a home audits will improve your home's re-sale value, lower your utility bills, and create a more comfortable living space. After having an audit and making improvements, the average household saves more than 20% on their total energy bill."Maryland Home Performance with ENERGY STAR." Maryland Energy Administration. n.d. 20 Jan, 2010 Some households have the potential to save as much as 40%."In Maryland, annual residential energy costs average $2400 per year. With the Maryland Home Performance with ENERGY STAR Program, potential exists to save between $200 and $950 per year by making the home more energy-efficient." "Maryland Home Performance with ENERGY STAR." Maryland Energy Administration. n.d. 20 Jan, 2010 Working with an auditor is the single biggest step you can take towards improving the overall performance of your home.

fields.content: Your fireplace is supposed to keep you warm, but leaky fireplaces often make your house colder by drawing warm air up the flue.

fields.name: Install a low-flow shower head
fields.content: The energy you save by switching will power your television for a year.Installing two low-flow shower heads will save the average household 300 kWh per year: WaterSense® Draft Specification for Showerheads Supporting Statement, p. 5A 32" LCD television on for 3 hours, every day uses 139.2 kWh of electricity a year: How much electricity does my stuff use?

fields.name: Change your air conditioning and heater filters every three months
fields.content: Clean filters help your system run efficiently, last longer, and improve indoor air quality.
fields.teaser: Change your air conditioning and heater filters every three months

fields.name: Use your ceiling fan in the summer
fields.content: Fans create a more comfortable home and lower cooling bills.
fields.teaser: Use your ceiling fan in the summer

fields.name: Seal off vents in unoccupied rooms
fields.content: Vent covers allow you to prevent unnecessary heating and cooling in hobby rooms, guest rooms, and other occasional-use spaces. Closing these vents will help your HVAC system work faster and use less energy.
fields.teaser: Seal off vents in unoccupied rooms

fields.name: Dial down your thermostat when you're at home
fields.content: You can save energy without sacrificing comfort.

fields.name: Wash your clothes in cold water
fields.content: If you wash your clothes in cold water instead of hot, your washing machine will use 90% less energy per load.Planet Green, Beat the Heat, Wash in Cold
fields.teaser: Wash your clothes in cold water

fields.name: Cut standby power
fields.content: 75% of the electricity used to power home electronics and appliances is consumed while the products are turned off.Department of Energy, Appliances & Electronics This "vampire" power accounts for 5-10% of your electric bill.Lawerence Berkley National Laboratory, Standby Power: FAQs

fields.name: Replace your windows
fields.content: New windows are an expensive upgrade with a longer payback period, so they probably shouldn't be first on your list. However, if you've already made other improvements, new windows can make a big difference in your your home's appearance and performance.

fields.name: Use a programmable thermostat
fields.content: Your home will be more comfortable when you're there, and more efficient when you're away.

fields.name: Have a home audit
fields.content: A home audit will give you the tools to understand and unlock the unique energy saving opportunities in your home.

fields.name: Insulate your water pipes
fields.content: Just like your water heater, adding insulation to your hot water pipes helps them stay hotter, longer. Insulated pipes deliver water that's 2ºF–4ºF hotter than uninsulated pipes, allowing you to turn your water heater down while maintaining your water heater temperature.Department of Energy, Energy Savers, Insulate Hot Water Pipes for Energy Saving Insulated pipes are also better protected against frost.

fields.name: Install a chimney draft guard
fields.content: Draft guards keep warm air where it belongs.

fields.name: Replace your incandescent light bulbs with CFLs
fields.content: CFLs are four times more efficient than outdated incandescent light bulbs.ToolBase Services, Compact Fluorescent Lighting Keep track of your progress with this list.
fields.teaser: Replace your incandescent light bulbs with CFLs

fields.name: Adjust the temperature setting on your water heater
fields.content: Lowering the temperature on your hot water heater prevents scalding and saves real energy. For every 10° you lower your water heater, you'll save around 5% on your water heating bill.American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, Consumer Guide to Home Energy Savings: Condensed Online Version, Water Heating
fields.teaser: Adjust the temperature setting on your water heater

fields.name: Insulate your water heater
fields.content: If the outside of your water heater feels warm, heat is escaping and your system could benefit from additional insulation.

fields.name: Replace your outdated refrigerator
fields.content: An Energy Star-rated refrigerator gives your kitchen a sleek, fresh look while saving a ton of energy.

fields.name: Caulk around your windows
fields.content: Savvy homeowners know that small gaps make a huge difference in energy bills. Luckily there's an easy solution: caulking. Caulking can seal gaps that are up to 1/4" wide. Tubes often cost less than $8, making caulking one of the best repairs you can do yourself.

fields.name: Insulate your windows
fields.content: Heat loss from your windows accounts for 10-25% of your winter heating bill."Energy Saver Tips: Windows." Energy Savers. Department of Energy. 22 Jan 2009. 25 Jan 2010. Inexpensive insulation kits create more comfortable rooms and lower bills.

fields.name: Set your computer to sleep automatically
fields.content: "Screen savers" don't save any energy, but sleep mode does. By activating sleep mode, you can $25-$75 per computer annually."Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)." ENERGY STAR. n.d. 27 Jan 2010.

fields.content: If you wash 80% of your loads in cold water for a year, you'll save more than $60 in energy costs.Planet Green, Beat the Heat, Wash in Cold There are many laundry detergents available that are specifically formulated to work with cold water, including Tide Coldwash and Woolite Liquid Cold Water Wash. As an added benefit of switching cycles, your clothes will last longer if they're washed in cold water.
fields.name: Switch your wash cycle

fields.content: You can eliminate vampire power by connecting all your electronics to power strips, and switching off the power strip after you're done using your devices. It's easy to forget to switch off your power strip every time, so "smart" power strips are here to make destroying vampire power even easier. They cut power to your electronics, either by linking all devices on the strip to a single control or by automatically switching everything off when one device, like the television, is powered down. They're perfect for the home entertainment or office areas.
fields.name: Buy a power strip

fields.content: Plug in your devices and start saving! Make sure you remember to switch your power strip off, or you won't actually see any savings.

fields.name: Identify the correct model for your home

fields.content: Buy the right thermostat for your system. If your home has electric heat, make sure to select one specifically for that system. Programmable thermostats are generally not compatible with heat pumps.

fields.content: Think about when you typically go to bed, leave in the morning, and come home at night. Set your thermostat to lower your heat or air-conditioning while you're asleep or at work, and turn the heat back up by the time you wake up or get home. During the winter, rolling back your thermostat from 72° to 65° for eight hours a day will save you 7% on your heating bill.Department of Energy, Energy Savers,

fields.content: The difference between 78° and 74° may not feel like much, but it has a big impact on your energy use. By permanently setting your thermostat to 78° instead of 74° during the summer, you'll save around 12% on your cooling bill.Christopher Solomon, MSN Real Estate

You should be able lower your thermostat enough to still feel comfortable and save around 10% on your heating bills.Kristin Underwood, Treehugger.com Turn Back Your Clock and Fan This Halloween for Better Energy Savings

fields.content: Sink aerators - small pieces that attach to your sinks - are widely available and very inexpensive: from about 50 cents to $3.00. For the bathroom, look for an aerator with a flow rate of between 0.5 to 1 gallon per minute. You can also install aerators in your kitchen, but kitchen sinks need a higher flow rate. Low-flow bathroom faucets can reduce a sink's water flow by 30 percent or more without sacrificing performance.EPA, WaterSense, Bathroom Sink Faucets & Accessories Look for the EPA WaterSense logo on aerators to ensure you're purchasing a low-flow version. The website MetaEfficient has reviews and purchasing information for some of the most popular sink aerators.

fields.content: CFLs can be used virtually everywhere. Certain CFLs can even be used with dimmers and other specialty lights. To find the right CFL for you, consult the Energy Star Buyer's Guide.

fields.content: CFLs are widely available. CFLs are a bit more expensive, but you'll easily recoup your investment in energy savings. One CFL will save you $30 over the bulb's lifetime, paying for itself in around six months.ENERGY STAR, "Green" Light Bulb Buying Guide CFLs also last up to ten times longer, meaning fewer trips to the hardware store.
fields.name: Buy the light bulbs

fields.content: You can buy caulk at virtually any hardware store. There are many different types of caulk available, but make sure you select a caulk designed to seal dissimilar materials. Butyl rubber caulk is one good choice.
fields.name: Select your caulk

fields.content: Wipe down the surface and scrape away any old caulk with a putty knife or screw driver. Make sure the surface is completely dry before you start.
fields.name: Clean the surface

fields.content:
Make sure to put caulk where the glass meets the frame and in the frame's joints. Caulking is an improvement you can easily do yourself, but it can take some practice to get it perfect. To perfect your form, try:
  • Holding the gun at a 45º angle, so the caulk is forced into cracks as it comes out.
  • Caulking continually, without multiple stops and starts.
  • Having the caulk stick to both sides of a gap.
fields.name: Caulk

fields.content: Window insulation kits contain a special plastic sheet and double-sided tape. The sheet traps air between the sheet and glass, creating an insulating barrier. Kits - like those from 3M and Ace - are easy to install and generally cost less than $4 per window.
fields.name: Buy a window insulation kit

fields.content: With just some scissors and a few minutes, you can stop uncomfortable drafts.
fields.name: Install the kit

fields.content:
The most energy efficient windows are double-paned and constructed with high-performance glass. "High- performance" means the glass is able to absorb or reflect light better than conventional glass. In cold areas, for example, "low-e" windows are a good choice. They readily absorb heat and reflect it back into the room. In warm areas, "spectrally selective" glass reduces heat gain while allowing light to pass through. 

Choosing the right window will make a big difference in your energy bills. A contractor will be able to tailor recommendations to your home's needs.
fields.name: Select high-performance windows

It's easy to customize your power management preferences. Set your computer to enter standby or hibernate mode after 30 to 60 minutes of inactivity. Have the monitor turn off after 20 minutes of inactivity.
  • For Windows Users: Start -> Control Panel -> Performance and Maintenance -> Power Options
  • For Mac Users: Applications -> System Preferences -> Energy Saver
